original_text: For all volunteers the AAMM technique significantly (p < 0.01) outperformed the other two methods in all of the intervals as can be seen by comparing to the error curves shown in Fig. 8 and the figures in Table 1 in the supplementary materials. Significance was assessed using a 1-tailed Wilcoxon signed rank test since the error distributions were generally not symmetric. The estimation errors for AAMM and its non-adaptive counterpart, AAMM (no adapt.), were similar in the beginning of the application phase, but as anticipated, as the application phase went on, the AAMM technique continually improved its accuracy by incorporating more and more data into the model. On average the motion estimation of AAMM improved by 22.94% in T5 with respect to its non-adaptive counterpart. However, the method has already significantly adapted to the breathing pattern in T2, i.e. after between 3 and 7 min of imaging, where motion estimations where on average 16.87% more accurate than at the beginning of the adaptation phase. By visually inspecting the curves for AAMM in Fig. 8 it can be seen that for many volunteers (in particular volunteers A, D, E, and F) the error curves start to flatten approximately around the 7 min mark. From this it can be concluded that a longer calibration scan of around 12 min would be optimal, that is the 5 min that were used for calibration in this experiment plus 7 min worth of data added during the application phase. Note that this time could be significantly reduced if a non-cardiac-gated sequence was used.
original_translation: Para todos los voluntarios, la técnica AAMM superó significativamente (p < 0.01) a los otros dos métodos en todos los intervalos, como se puede observar al comparar las curvas de error mostradas en la Figura. 8 y las cifras en la Tabla 1 en los materiales suplementarios. La significancia se evaluó utilizando una prueba de rango con signo de Wilcoxon de una cola, ya que las distribuciones de error generalmente no eran simétricas. Los errores de estimación para AAMM y su contraparte no adaptativa, AAMM (no adapt.), fueron similares al principio de la fase de aplicación, pero como se anticipaba, a medida que avanzaba la fase de aplicación, la técnica AAMM mejoraba continuamente su precisión al incorporar más y más datos en el modelo. En promedio, la estimación de movimiento de AAMM mejoró un 22.94% en T5 en comparación con su contraparte no adaptativa. Sin embargo, el método ya se ha adaptado significativamente al patrón de respiración en T2, es decir, después de entre 3 y 7 minutos de imágenes, donde las estimaciones de movimiento fueron en promedio un 16.87% más precisas que al principio de la fase de adaptación. Al inspeccionar visualmente las curvas para AAMM en la Fig. 8, se puede observar que para muchos voluntarios (en particular los voluntarios A, D, E y F) las curvas de error comienzan a aplanarse aproximadamente alrededor del minuto 7. De esto se puede concluir que un escaneo de calibración más largo de alrededor de 12 minutos sería óptimo, es decir, los 5 minutos que se utilizaron para la calibración en este experimento más 7 minutos de datos agregados durante la fase de aplicación. Ten en cuenta que este tiempo podría reducirse significativamente si se utilizara una secuencia no sincronizada con el corazón.

8 and the figures in Table 1 in the supplementary materials.
Significance was assessed using a 1-tailed Wilcoxon signed rank test since the error distributions were generally not symmetric.

The estimation errors for AAMM and its non-adaptive counterpart, AAMM (no adapt. ), were similar in the beginning of the application phase, but as anticipated, as the application phase went on, the AAMM technique continually improved its accuracy by incorporating more and more data into the model.
On average the motion estimation of AAMM improved by 22.94% in T5 with respect to its non-adaptive counterpart.

However, the method has already significantly adapted to the breathing pattern in T2, i.e. after between 3 and 7 min of imaging, where motion estimations where on average 16.87% more accurate than at the beginning of the adaptation phase.

By visually inspecting the curves for AAMM in Fig. 8 it can be seen that for many volunteers (in particular volunteers A, D, E, and F) the error curves start to flatten approximately around the 7 min mark.

From this it can be concluded that a longer calibration scan of around 12 min would be optimal, that is the 5 min that were used for calibration in this experiment plus 7 min worth of data added during the application phase.
Note that this time could be significantly reduced if a non-cardiac-gated sequence was used.

For all volunteers the AAMM technique significantly (p < 0.01) outperformed the other two methods in all of the intervals as can be seen by comparing to the
error curves
shown in Fig.
8 and the figures in Table 1 in the supplementary materials.
Significance was assessed using a 1-tailed Wilcoxon signed rank test since the error distributions were generally not symmetric.

The estimation errors for AAMM and its non-adaptive counterpart, AAMM (no adapt. ), were similar in the beginning of the application phase, but as anticipated, as the application phase went on, the AAMM technique continually improved its accuracy by incorporating more and more data into the model.
On average the motion estimation of AAMM improved by 22.94% in T5 with respect to its non-adaptive counterpart.

However, the method has already significantly adapted to the breathing pattern in T2, i.e. after between 3 and 7 min of imaging, where motion estimations where on average 16.87% more accurate than at the beginning of the adaptation phase.

By visually inspecting the curves for AAMM in Fig. 8 it can be seen that for many volunteers (in particular volunteers A, D, E, and F) the
error curves
start to flatten approximately around the 7 min mark.

From this it can be concluded that a longer calibration scan of around 12 min would be optimal, that is the 5 min that were used for calibration in this experiment plus 7 min worth of data added during the application phase.
Note that this time could be significantly reduced if a non-cardiac-gated sequence was used.

error curves
shown in Fig.

By visually inspecting the curves for AAMM in Fig. 8 it can be seen that for many volunteers (in particular volunteers A, D, E, and F) the

start to flatten approximately around the 7 min mark.
